structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, WMS service, downloadable vector and raster formats
structured_data.data_format: Vector, Raster, WMS
structured_data.description: The WEBMAP EPE provides an updated interactive map of the Brazilian energy system, offering information, transparency, and accessibility to society. It allows users to query, download data in vector and raster formats, measure areas and distances, add their own data, and print maps from georeferenced data used in national energy sector planning studies. It also allows sharing geographic layers as WMS services and consulting metadata. The map includes layers for planned and existing electrical systems, biofuels, liquid fuels infrastructure, natural gas infrastructure, oil and gas exploration and production, environment, and EPE studies and energy resources. It covers UHE, PCH, CGH, thermal power plants, wind farms, photovoltaic plants, transmission lines and substations, oil and gas fields, biofuel units, and natural gas and liquid fuels infrastructure, among other geoinformation, and relates energy sector information with environmental themes like protected areas (conservation units, indigenous or quilombola lands).

The 2017 edition, released after nine years, covers cadastral and operational data on water capture, collection, treatment, distribution, and billing, as well as sewage collection, treatment, and disposal across all Brazilian municipalities. It also includes aspects related to delegation instruments, service charges, personnel, and occurrences of water rationing and intermittency. The survey provides a valuable overview of water supply and sewage management in Brazil.

structured_data.description: The IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics) updates the Brazilian municipal and intermediate meshes annually, providing shapefiles. The dataset includes municipal boundaries, immediate geographic regions, intermediate geographic regions, states (UF), and the country's boundaries for 2023 and 2024. The 2020 version of the Digital Municipal Mesh is constituted by 5572 geocodes, including 5568 Municipalities, 1 Federal District, 1 State District, and 2 Operational State Areas. The data is provided by IBGE.

structured_data.name: Base de Faces de Logradouros do Brasil

structured_data.description: Geo-referenced geospatial database of lines representing street faces in urbanized areas, urban expansions, and rural agglomerations across Brazil. It includes attributes for street names, territorial structure by Census Sectors, and the National Address Register for Statistical Purposes (CNEFE). The base is updated after each Demographic Census and continuously between Censuses through analysis of high-resolution orbital and aerial images and field campaigns. The 2022 preliminary results incorporate updates from the 2022 Demographic Census collection, representing 13,854,931 line segments.

structured_data.temporal_coverage: Initial construction from 2007 Censuses, continuously updated, with preliminary results for 2022 (referencing July 31 to August 1, 2022).

structured_data.data_format: PDF
structured_data.description: This study diagnoses the environmental vulnerability of Environmental Protection Areas (APA) within the Atlantic Forest Biome in the southeastern region of Brazil. It uses Geographic Information System (GIS) data including slope, geology, pedology, and land use/occupation to determine an Environmental Vulnerability Index. The results indicate predominantly low to medium vulnerability in the studied areas, highlighting the need for actions to reduce degradation from agricultural and urban expansion. The study is essential for territorial planning and management plans for Conservation Units.

These studies provide digital files representing all Brazilian municipalities and the country's total area, based on new legislation, judicial decisions, and technical reports from state agencies. The 2022 edition includes maps for 174 municipalities with updated limits between May 2021 and July 2022. The total territorial area of Brazil for 2022 is 8,510,417.771 km², an adjustment due to international border edits in certain states. The data is continuously updated based on geotechnologies and agreements with state legislative bodies.

It also features mining-related processes like active mining processes, protection areas, leases, blocked areas, and garimpeiro reserves from ANM. The map viewer uses Earthstar Geographics and IBGE for geographical base layers.

structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF map via FTP link

structured_data.description: A mural map and accompanying text by IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics) illustrating the spatial distribution of transportation logistics in Brazil. It highlights the predominance of road transport, its concentration in the South-Central region, and the importance of fluvial transport in the Amazon. The map displays key transport infrastructure (roads, railways, waterways) and associated logistics equipment (warehouses, dry ports, border points, public aerodromes, waterway terminals). The data sources include the Ministry of Transport, ANTAQ, ANAC, DNIT, INFRAERO, and the Federal Revenue of Brazil. The map aims to contribute to the analysis and construction of a new geography of the country, understanding transport logistics as a structuring dimension of the Brazilian urban network and national connections. The release was published on 25/11/2014 and updated on 27/05/2019.

last_structured_review_details.overall_assessment_notes: The extracted structured data provides a strong foundation for a CCRA exposure assessment in Brazil, particularly for infrastructure. Several datasets from credible sources like IBGE, ANEEL, EPE, and MapBiomas offer detailed geospatial information on transportation, energy, and sanitation infrastructure, as well as built-up areas and demographic characteristics. While some entries are less directly relevant (e.g., land cover fractions without explicit infrastructure links, or general demographic publications without spatial data), the core infrastructure datasets are highly valuable. The availability of municipal-level data and continuous updates from official sources enhances the potential for a robust assessment. There are some gaps in specific critical infrastructure categories (e.g., hospitals, schools explicitly) and detailed economic/financial indicators directly linked to infrastructure assets, but the existing data can serve as a strong base.
last_structured_review_details.relevance_reasoning: The data includes numerous entries directly related to infrastructure (energy, transport, sanitation, built-up areas) and demographic/population characteristics at relevant spatial scales for Brazil. Key sources like IBGE, ANEEL, EPE, and MapBiomas provide geospatial data crucial for exposure assessment.
last_structured_review_details.credibility_reasoning: The majority of the data originates from highly credible Brazilian government agencies (IBGE, ANEEL, EPE, ANM), well-regarded research initiatives (MapBiomas, GHSL), and established international organizations (OpenStreetMap, Esri Demographics). These sources are authoritative and regularly updated.
last_structured_review_details.completeness_reasoning: While there is substantial data on energy, transportation, and general built-up areas, specific critical infrastructure categories like hospitals, schools, and emergency services are not explicitly detailed in the extracted data. Economic and financial indicators directly tied to infrastructure assets (e.g., replacement costs, insurance coverage) are also less prominent, though SINAPI provides construction costs which could be a proxy. Demographic data is good, but specific socioeconomic vulnerability indicators (e.g., poverty rates at fine spatial resolution) could be further enhanced. The spatial resolution and temporal coverage are generally good for the available data.
last_structured_review_details.action_reasoning: The extracted data provides a comprehensive and credible set of exposure infrastructure datasets for Brazil, covering key sectors like energy, transportation, and sanitation, along with essential demographic and built-environment information. The sources are highly authoritative, and the spatial and temporal resolutions are generally suitable for CCRA. While some specific critical infrastructure types and detailed economic indicators could be further explored, the current collection is robust enough to proceed with analysis.
last_structured_review_details.refinement_details: Future refinement could focus on identifying specific datasets for critical social infrastructure (hospitals, schools) and more granular economic vulnerability indicators at sub-municipal levels, if available.
